PIGLETHROWER




About Piglethrower

Development time: 2 weeks
Release date: June 2012

Piglethrower was my first game ever, I did it as a university project on 2nd year for "JTP" course ("Języki i Techniki Programowania", which can be translated to "Programming Languages and Techniques"), where we were learning programming in Java for the first time. I had little to no programming skills, even though I was already familiar with a little bit of C, C++ and OOP. I didn't even know what version control, unit testing, design patterns, software engineering, frameworks etc. were. I wasn't even using java packages! Every class was in default package. I am surprised this game works and of course its code quality sucks, but I still love it. I was relying heavily on Black Art of Java Game Programming book back then (I should totally read it again), which is awesome but a little bit outdated. It taught me how to use interfaces and other good practices, but as my codebase grew it became a total spaghetti.

Fun fact: at first I was planning to use my photoshopped head instead of a pig and the goal was to eat brains instead of apples. So it was supposed to be a zombie-themed game. My professor said it is not allowed and that I had to came up with something more serious. So I came up with a piglet jumping around to epic sax guy! Eat that, professor! Below are sprites used in the very early stage of development, when I was testing picking my head up and letting it fall down:

(old falling animation)

(old idle animation)

(old holding animation)

The rules of the game are simple - grab a pig by pressing a mouse button and throw it by moving the cursor and releasing the button. You have 10 moves, there are 10 apples and only 1 level. There is a small circular area around your character telling you how far you can move. After crossing it, the pig will be released automatically.

This game isn't polished or anything - physics are a joke, collision detection is implemented so badly that you can literally move through walls, but it was a big achievement for me at the time and I am still proud of it. I particularly like the character - I have drawn and animated this pig myself and I think it looks good, especially the falling animation (you can even see little tears of fear in the corner of its eyes):


(current falling animation)

(current idle animation)

(current holding animation)


I've learned alot during the process and loved every second of it. Game mechanics like picking things up and letting gravity take them down were pretty simple to come up with, but very difficult for a novice programmer to implement. After I figured it out and it worked for the first time I spent many minutes fooling around with it and I have had alot of fun! It was like playing with a toy I invented myself.

Play

You may have problems (application and security errors) if you will try to play it here - the game was written as a Java Applet which is something like a Java program running in the browser, but it is not very popular, considered a safety threat and therefore hard to run using a modern browser.

It is not impossible, just install newest Java and Java Runtime Environment and then follow those steps:

  1. Go to Control Panel on Windows.
  2. Select JAVA (you may have to search for it).
  3. Go to "Security" tab.
  4. Click "Edit Site List".
  5. Click "Add".
  6. Paste URL of this site there (http://celebes.github.io/games/piglethrower/).
  7. Click "Ok".
  8. Click "Continue" on security warning.
After all that extra work you should get a new warning (yay!) with 3 choices - select "run" and you should be able to play!

There are some problems with the music sadly, just play epic sax guy 10 hours on youtube and keep it in the background for full immersion..
